title: Review of the rewrite
body:
- Removes inconsistencies
- A Zone can only contain Singular Assertion
- Remove UDP support for RAINS
- Simplifies some large sentences
- Fixes Types

title: Reorganize document to be a more useful protocol spec
body:
This involves:

- adding content from the dead [-inip-pins](/britram/pins) draft to explain why we're doing this
- removing the data model / infomodel split, making clear that CBOR is *the* MTI data model for RAINS

**DO NOT MERGE THIS PR YET** this is work in progress, primarily as a PR so we can look at diffs.

title: Assertion CBOR representation change of objects field
body:
As an assertion can only have one type, it does not make sense to store the type with the object type. This way the type is duplicated in case an assertions contains several values of a certain type.
Solution:
Remove the cbor type object
Add a field 'Type' to Assertion which is an integer representing a type.
Add a field 'Value' to Assertion which is a CBOR array containing values of the assertion's type.

title: Runtime consistency checks
body:
The following entries must be updated due to the changed semantics of sections proving non-existence:
A shard omits an assertion within its range whose validSince value is equal to the shard's.
A zone omits an assertion within its zone whose validSince value is equal to the zone's.

The following inconsistency can occur:
A server returns an assertion whose validSince value is smaller than the validSince value of a zone or shard in range and the assertion is not part of the zone or shard after it has sent the shard or zone. 

Additionally, a new action should be added to the Message processing section:
On receipt of a shard or zone message section, a server:
Should remove all assertions in range with a smaller validSince value that are not present in the shard or zone.

The draft states this inconsistency: "A zone contains a valid reflexive assertion of a given object type at the same time that its superordinate zone contains a valid assertion of the same type." but also makes a preference when both occur: "If an assertion of a given type about a zone is available both in the zone itself and in the superordinate zone, the assertion in the superordinate zone will take precedence."

Due to glue records it can happen that both occur and IMO it should be fine with the preference notion.

title: Next key and extra key object is missing keyphase
body:
The extra key is currently defined by algorithm type and keyspace.
I suggest to add a keyphase as well such that external keys can also be rolled over seemlessly.
The next key obeject certainly needs a key phase otherwise the superordinate cannot issue a correct delegation.

title: Do we really need 504 No Assertion Available?
body: We know (at the client) when the query timed out.

title: add semantics; structure to note-data for automated error handling
body: Specifically, notification codes 400, 403, and 413 could use additional data.

title: Specify how to find local query servers
body: This is out of scope for now but we should specify something. DSCP? PvD? mDNS/mRAINS? some custom discovery protocol?

title: Rollup fixes to specification, Update queries, bloom filters, negative proof semantics
Bloom filter as space efficient non-existence proofs
Update request Queries for Assertion, shard and zone
New semantic of shards
body:
Shards show the state of the zone at the time it was signed. It can be used until its lifetime ends but there might be inconsistencies, i.e. a new assertion might be valid although the shard does not contain it.
It is not a proof of non-existence throughout its lifetime anymore.
This change allows the system to be dynamic by e.g. having new assertions available instantly, to change ranges of shards, make changes to assertion, etc.

title: Usage of sections
body:
Assertion only for positive answers
Shards only for negative answers
Zone for positive and negative answer. (Most zones are tiny and not dynamic, once cached it can be used to answer both with few bytes.

title: Mode of operation on positive cache miss
body:
Add 3 query options for
- always do recursive lookup
- check in neg cache and on hit, send update query and inform client about possible neg result
- on neg cache hit, send cached answer back (might be inconsistent)

A server can be configured to use all or only some of them. Maybe dependent on the current load it has.

title: Alternate methods to verify a delegation chain given signature failure near the root
body: In case an authority higher up in the delegation chain messes up and is not able to sign all delegation assertions in time and serve them throughout there validity period, all subzones become unavailable. In such a worst case scenario there should be a mechanism for the subzones to still be reachable during a transition period maybe through accepting assertions with a broken delegation chain. We have to be careful that such a mechanism cannot be misused or only in a very limited fashion.

title: Add sorting definition of object value for each type
body: Assertions must be sorted deterministically for signature validation in shards. So far the draft only sorts assertions by their name, But there might be assertions for different types and even several assertions per type. We have to define an order on the types (I suggest their code number) and for each type how the objects of this type are sorted.

title: Delegation only zones do not exist
body:
Remove this part?

"There are three kinds of zones;
treating these zones differently may allow lookup protocol
optimizations:

- Zones containing only delegation assertions are delegation-only zones.
  Delegation-only zones are not relevant as part of an assertion lookup, other
  than for discovering and verifying authority. Top-level domains are
  generally delegation-only.
- Zones containing no delegation assertions are final zones. Final zones are
  not relevant as part of an authority discovery.
- Zones containing at least one delegation assertion and at least one
  assertion that is not a delegation assertion are mixed zones. No
  optimizations are available for mixed zones."

For bootstrapping and recursive lookup to work, a zone needs to have a delegation, ip and redirect assertions. Thus, the first kind of zone cannot exist. The final one cannot be used to optimize. For the second one, there is no guarantee that it will not start delegating in the future. Therefore, a querier first has to make sure that the zone is still final in which case he could have sent directly a delegation query.

title: Does the infrakey has a key phase?
body: "It is identical in structure to a delegation object, as defined in {{cbor-signature}}"

title: keyphase in delegation query
body: A query for a delegation assertion must contain the keyphase. Otherwise a caching resolver could always send a cached delegation of a different keyphase

title: Delegation assertion needs keyphase
body: Delegation assertion must contain the keyphase of the contained public key.

title: Dot '.' in subject zone or subject name allowed
body: Mention it in the query processing part, to ensure that a reference implementation implements splitting a query's FQDM correctly.

title: Restrict size of shards, remove zone?
body:
Shards and zones can be misused in an amplification attack. To restrict the strength of such an attack, a shard should have a maximum number of contained assertions and an Assertion is only allowed to have a restricted number of objects.

Shards and zones are intended as a proof of non existence for a name. Instead of directly sending a potentially large message back to the client, we could send a notification message which states that the name does not exist. In case the user does not trust this message, as the DNS resolver is dishonest or there was a man in the middle attack, he can afterwards still request a shard as a non-existence proof. Latency to obtain the shard is less critical in this circumstance as the name in a regular case does not exist. In case the client made a typo in entering the domain name, he will either end up on the wrong site or quickly receive a non-existence notification message. In both cases he can quickly correct the name and end up on the right site.

title: Bootstrapping
body: In operational considerations: Add how bootstrapping is done, i.e. which assertions are necessary and by whom they are signed.

title: Split DNS use case (context)
body: make the example more clear (see scion book)

title: Server-Server vs Server-Client behavior
body:
"Servers only process query and notification sections when connected to clients; a client sending assertions to a server results in a 400 Bad Message notification."

How does a server know if a connection is initiated by a client or by a server? If it cannot distinguish the two it also cannot act accordingly.

title: Multiple Types per Assertion
body:
Page 5: "A mapping between a name and object(s) of specified types"
Sec 4.1: "Each Assertion is about a single type of data."

I would go with a single type per Assertion. Most queries will be about a single type - ip4 or ip6. This way, the answers to these queries will be short as they contain only relevant information.
Note that an assertion can contain multiple entries of the same type. This is especially important for the delegation type as we want to send public keys of multiple key phases to prevent interruption.

title: Message Section vs Message Content
body:
Sec 5.4 and following: "...Assertion is contained in a Message Section"
An Assertion is a Message Section (according to Sec 5.2)
Replace it with "... Assertion is contained in a Message's Content"

The same phrase is used for Shards, Zones and Address Assertions as well.

title: lexicographic sorting of shards and assertions
body:
Sec 5.6: "Shards and Assertions in the content array SHOULD be sorted by shard range or name in ascending lexicographic order."

I would make it explicit how it is sorted because for me it is not clear. Is it this way?
assertions are sorted before shards. 
assertions are sorted lexicographically ascending by subject-name
shards are sorted lexicographically ascending firstly by range begin and secondly by range end?

title: shard range sentence simplification
body:
"Shards are lexicographically complete within the range described in the shard-range value: a mapping for a subject-name that should be between the two values given in the range but is not is asserted to not exist."

replace with

"Shards are lexicographically complete within the range described in the shard-range value: a subject-name within the shard-range that is not contained in the shard is asserted to not exist."

title: 4.3.1. Context in Address Assertions
body:
"Authorities have complete control over how the contexts under their namespaces are arranged, and over the names within those contexts."

Address assertions are about network addresses. Should it not be control over addresses instead of names under their namespaces?

title: Information element 'kind' on zones
body:
Sec 4.1.3: “A zone has the following information elements: … Kind: delegation-only, final, or mixed"”
This information element is not represented in the CBOR data model.
Do we want to add this information to a zone or remove it?

title: Lexicographic completeness of shards
body:
Page 5, Shard: " A group of assertions common to a zone, with common signatures, which may be lexicographically complete..."
Page 20: "Shards are lexicographically complete within the range described in its the shard-range value"

According to the draft it is not clear, if shards MUST be lexicographically complete.
Adv: They can be used as a proof of non-existence
Disadv: It restricts the protocol. There might be cases where it makes sense to group some assertions together in a shard instead sending all assertions separately. E.g. it makes sure that either all or none of the assertions are received.

Mitigation: If we do not want to restrict ourselves and have non-existence proofs, we could add a flag to the shard which indicates that it is lexicographic complete.

title: FQDNs and context names have dots at the end.
body: For consistency, clarity, and DNS compatibility.

title: Contained sections in Shards and Zones must be sorted
Eliminate Addresszones
body: Is it necessary to have negative proofs for reverse lookup? If so it must be clear by which Addresszone an addressAssertion was signed which is currently not the case.

title: add RAINS Publication Protocol (for rainspub)
body: send only messages containing assertion/zone/shard, receive only notifications. any new notifications needed for publication protocol?

title: explicitly define the implicit root in local contexts
Add 'Publish entity' additionally to servers and clients
body: For an authority to publish sections to its servers it does not need a full-fledged server. But a server only accept queries from clients. Thus we need a third instance which can send sections to servers and the servers only accept these sections if this instance is in the authority source list. Otherwise a 400 bad message notification is sent back to the sender.

title: Capability handling
body:
If we send the capability answer back on a message, then the server has to keep state of the capability it has to send on the next message. Which in turn implicates that before a server can send a message it always has to check if there is a capability it has to add to the message. By sending it directly back, we do not have to check on every future message if there is a capability we have to add. Thus, I propose the following protocol to handle capabilities where at most 3 notifications are exchanged after establishing a connection.

if connection is not yet cached, establish new connection and add capabilities to first message.
on receive of a msg with capability and hash understood: send a message back containing a notification(type: capabilityAnswer,  data: <hash of own capabilities>)
on receive of a msg with capability and hash not understood: send a message back containing a notification(type:capability hash not understood, data:<hash of own capability>)
on receive of a notification capabilityAnswer and other capability understood: notice capability
on receive of a notification capabilityAnswer and other capability not understood: send a msg 
containing notification(type: capability hash not understood, data:<no data>)
on receive of a notification capability not understood and other capability understood: send a msg containing notification(type: capabilityAnswer, data:<list of own capabilities>)
on receive of a notification capability not understood and other capability not understood: send a msg containing notification(type: capability hash not understood, data:<list of own capabilities>)
on receive of a notification capability not understood and with no capability data: send a msg containing notification(type: capabilityAnswer, data:<list of own capabilities>)

This approach also allows servers which only push information to negotiate capabilities and upgrade their connection.

title: Keyphase
body: Add an integer to a delegation object and also to the signature meta data to specify the key phase of the public key.

title: shorter title names, token mandatory for messages, typos
context must not be present in contained sections
typos, consistency, expired fields
body:
removed some typos.
Added possible inconsistencies of address assertions and zones
expired fields for queries are mandatory

title: Representation of delegation object in an assertion
body:
Right now a delegation Object is represented as a N-element array.
From an implementation perspective it would be better to have a 3 element array instead where the first 2 elements are the same but the third element is a cbor array containing the elements of the public key. So we can decouple the parsing of the delegation object form the parsing of the public key data.
We then also do not have to define concatenation of different values of a public key (such as x and y in ECDSA or in any other future algorithm.
